_accidents.CF_Other: drained to sewer and was neutralized

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
At Domtar Paper Company, LLC -Hawesville Mill, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency reponse planning programs to help ensure the safetly of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehenisve risk mangement activities that we have desgined and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation
* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases
* An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
* A five-year accident history from accidental releases of chemical regulated by EPA's RMP rule
* An overview of our emergency response program

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Our facility produces bleached market pulp, and fine papers using a variety of chemicals and processing operations.  The bleached pulp portion uses a kraft pulping process and supplies fiber to the fine paper manufacturing facility as well as manufacturing baled market pulp.  In our processes, we use the following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accident release:

Toxics

A 1% solution of chlorine dioxide is stored in 140,000 gallon tanks and is used to bleach hardwood kraft pulp.

Flammables 

No RMP list flammables are on site.  However, propane is stored in 1000 gallon tanks and is used to fuel the material handling equipment on site.  Additionally, the PSM regulated chemical methanol, is stored on site in a 19,000 gallon tank.  

Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage

the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals.

KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS

EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case release scenario(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario:

Worst-case Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Toxic Chemicals

This scenario assumes the rupture of a full, 140,000 gallon tank containing a 1% chlorine dioxide solution and the vaporization of the released solution.  The tank has dikes present to mitigate the extent of the release.  The model suggests the off site consequences would be in the area defined by a circle with the radius of 4.78 miles from the source (mill).

Alternative Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Toxic Chemicals

The scenario assumes a 1% chlorine dioxide solution process pipe leak.  This leak results in the release of the contents of an eight (8) inch pipe, 250 feet in length.  The scenario assumes no mitigation, and a release of 55 pounds of chlorine dioxide that is vapoized from the liquid release.  The models suggests the area impacted by the off site consequences would be defined by a circle with the diameter of 1.3 miles from the release site (mill).

Worst-case Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

This scenario assumes that a 1000 gallon propane storage tank has a leak that results in a vapor cloud explosion.  It also assumes no mitigation is present.  The model suggests there would be no off site consequences since the model endpoint would be 663 feet (0.12 miles) from the source and the nearest off site receptor in 1850 feet away (0.35 miles).

Alternative Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

The scenario assumes a pool fire resulting from a pipe failure/tank contents release o

f a 1000 gallon propane storage tank.  The model suggests the effects would be limited to a circle defined with a radius of 363 feet (0.07 miles).  There would be no off site consequence because the closest off site receptor is 1850 feet away (0.35 miles).

We are using the information to help us ensure that our emergency reponse plan and the community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:

* Process safety information
* Process hazard analysis
* Operating procedures
* Training
* Mechanical integrity
* Management of change
* Pre-startup review
* Compliance audits
* Incident investigation
* Employee participation
* Hot work permit
* Contractors

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

We keep records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:

3/24/07  An estimated 265 gallons of chlorine dioxide solution was released as the result of a pressure tap gasket failure.  The solution was contained and neutralized with thiosulfate.  The process was shutdown until repairs were completed.  An estimated 2.69 pounds was released to the atmosphere.

2/21/07  Approximately 312 gallons of chlorine dioxide solution was released as a result of a contractor

vacuum truck backing into and breaking a line supplying chlorine dioxide solution to the sand filter and paper machine areas.  The spill was contained and neutralized with thiosulfate in the secondary containment structure.  The process was shutdown and the line repaired. Approximately 1.45 lbs volatilized into the atmosphere.

5/28/06  An estimated three gallons of chlorine dioxide solution was released when a pressure readout tap gasket failed.  The chlorine dioxide solution was neutralized in the sewer by alkaline effluent and the gasket repaired. 

3/27/06  Approximately three gallons of chlorine dioxide solution was released with the gasket failed at an injection point for the sand filter.  The solution was neutralized by contact with organic material (gravel) and the gasket was repaired.


9/26/05 The bleach plant acid sewer plugged and allowed approximately 11 pounds of chlorine dioxide to flash from solution in the sewer.  The gas was contained and neutralized in the sewer and manhole.

9/23/05  A gasket failed on a chlorine dioxide solution pump allowing approximately 20 gallons to flow to the mill sewer.  The chlorine dioxide solution was neutralized in the sewer by alkaline effluent and the gasket repaired.


2/22/05  Approximately 11.25 pounds of chlorine dioxide solution was released over a 2.5 hour length of time when a valve on the D1 Bleach Tower failed.  The Valve was replaced.

12/5/04  Approximately 60 mls (0.06 liters) was released as a result of a flange gasket failure on a pressure transmitter signal line.  All the release was fully contained and neutralized.  The gasket was repaired.

9/28/04  Approximately 3.75 gallons of 0.1% chlorine dioxide solution was released as a result of a pipe leak at a flange in the chlorine dioxide storage area.  The release was full contained and neutralized and the flange repaired.

6/1/04    An estimated 120 mls of chlorine dioxide solution when a gasket on a pressure signal line for a storage tank failed.  The

material was contained and neutralized and the gasket replaced.

2/15/04  Approximately 1 gallon of chlorine dioxide solution was released when a pipe flange on a drain line in the No. 2 Bleach Plant failed.  The bolts in the flange worked lose resulting in the release.  All material was contained and neutralized.

3/13/03  Approximately 150 gallons of chlorine dioxide solution (1%) was spilled when a gasket on the bleaching tower supply line failed.  All the material was contained and neutralized.

8/27/02  A drain valve on the supply line to the FPM process was accidentally left open by the operator after completion of maintenance.  (The operator had shutdown and drained the line to allow maintenance to be performed.  As a result, 390 gallons of 1% chlorine dioxide was lost to the sewer.  The lost solution was diluted and neutralized in the sewer.  




Summary of Accidental Chemical Releases
2007  two (2) accidental releases
2006  two (2) accidental releases
2005  three (3) accidental releases
2004  four (4) accidental chemical releases
2003  one (1) accidental chemical release (to date)
2002  one (1) accidental chemcial release






EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the community emergency response plan.  

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Continue audits of the RMP/PSM system under the PSM audit program and make changes in response to the action items discovered in those audit findings.
